question_text: A 68-year-old woman with chronic plaque psoriasis is evaluated for a new extensive rash that developed shortly after she completed a course of systemic glucocorticoids prescribed for an exacerbation of COPD.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: Erythroderma is the most likely diagnosis (Option B). Erythroderma is defined as redness and scaling of 80% to 90% of the body surface area. It primarily affects middle-aged men and is often associated with an underlying condition, although 40% of cases are idiopathic. Patients with a history of psoriasis who are treated with systemic glucocorticoids, often for another condition, may develop a widespread erythrodermic or pustular flare when the glucocorticoids are discontinued. The presence of alopecia, nail dystrophy, and thickening of the palms and soles are similarly indicative of a long-standing underlying cause of erythroderma, such as cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, graft-versus-host disease, psoriasis, or pityriasis rubra pilaris. Erythroderma may be complicated by loss of fluid and heat across the inflamed skin.
